purposename: Plant and post-harvest protection and pest control
longdescription: The programme is expected to contribute to increased productivity in agriculture while at the same time contributing to a reduction in the use of pesticides and improvements in the environment. The programme is also expected to contribute to increasing the awareness among farmers about the links between inputs, farming systems and production output. The focus is primarily on rice cultivation, but also horticulture and vegetable production are targeted. The field level training will be conducted through Farmer Field Schools (FFS), and includes training of trainers, preparation of extension materials and support to farmers organisations. These activities are expected to contribute to empowerment of farmers and communities. The programme will be operational throughout the country. The Goal of the Programme is to contribute to sustainable broad-based poverty alleviation and food security while contributing to human healt and environmental protection.The objectives of the Programme are:(i) to contribute to institutionalise a sustainable national Integrated Pest Management Programme (IPM) in Nepal by strengthening the capacity of the Plant Protection Directorate (PPD), collab

shortdescription: DEVELOPMENT OF THE THREE YEAR STRATEGIC PLAN FOR BLUE DIAMOND SOCIETY
projecttitle: Development of the Three Year Strategic Plan for Blue Diamond Society
longdescription: The organisational review recommended that Blue Diamond Society develops a strategic plan. The overall objective of this project is to formulate the next three years plan to make effective interventions in the context of social, political and economic climate to advance and ensure sexual and gender minority equality in Nepal. Output:  A clear three year strategic plan with thorough review of the past achievement and forthcoming challenges BDS will come out with concrete and strategic programme actions for next three year period. This plan will be a set of guiding principles and define BDS s priorities. This plan of action will give verifying indicators of BDS achievements for outputs and outcomes and help focus on achieving impacts and results. Hence this plan will be the basis to implement overall BDS programs in a practical manner.

shortdescription: IMPLEMENTATION OF NATIONAL ACTION PLAN UNSCR 1325 AND 1820
projecttitle: Implementation of National Action Plan UNSCR 1325 and 1820
longdescription: Funds for the preparation of the NAP were channeled through WAPPDCA during the NAP preparation phase in 2010 (NOK 264885). The donor community has also been requested to support its implementation. Priority areas for support will be defined in consultation with the Government and other members of the Peace Support Working Group for 1325 and 1820.  Showcasing the Nepal experience will also be included in the follow-up phase. It is relevant to share the experience with other countries, with UN agencies HQ and other relevant agencies, since this has been a multi-stakeholder cooperation between the Government of Nepal, civil society and the international community (donors). Nepal has set an example by having such a strong collaboration and consultative process throughout the country in the prepartion of the NAP.

shortdescription: DOCUMENTARY FOR GENDER SENSITIVE REHABILITATION AND INTEGRATION OF PLA
projecttitle: Documentary for Gender Sensitive Rehabilitation and Integration of PLA
purposename: Civilian peace-building, conflict prevention and resolution
longdescription: Saferworld has recently, with the Embassy s support, completed research on the different needs and priorities of men and women qualified/eligible Maoist Army combatants for rehabilitation back into society and integration into security agencies. The research also focused on the views of communities on rehabilitation and integration and in particular how these differ by and towards men and women. Recommendations for strengthening the gender sensitivity of security agencies emerging from the research and suggestions made by different target groups included the need to raise public awareness on the positive and necessary role women can play in the delivery of security. The goal of the project is to strengthen effectiveness and gender sensitivity of policy and programming on integration and rehabilitation which in turn, will contribute to the promotion of a gender-sensitive integration and peace process and the implementation of recently agreed National Action Plan on United Nations Security Council Resolution (UNSCR) 1325.  Objective: To raise awareness of the public and security agency personnel on the positive and necessary role women can play in the delivery of security and in secu

The expected outcomes of the 2010-2012 programme are 1) to achieve financial and institutional sustainability, 2) to preserve and promote  the traditional and indigenous cultures and performance forms, 3) to strengthen other theatre groups in Aarohan's national and international network.The objectives are sought fulfilled through four main groups of activities: 1) Performances, 2) Workshops, 3) National, regional and international exchanges, 4) Documentation.Target groups: - For the theatre activities the target groups are Nepali people (audience) including rural villagers, dalits, ethnic minorities and other marginalised groups, in addition to theatre groups and social activities  - For the workshops and exchanges it is theatre artists from Aarohan itself and their national and international partners which are the target group. - For activities connected to cultural documentation the main target groups are local communities, researchers, universities, theatre people, media and the general public.

shortdescription: MULTI DONOR TRUST FUND FOR PUBLIC FINANCIAL MANAGEMENT (WB)
projecttitle: Multi Donor Trust Fund for Public Financial Management (WB)
longdescription: The background for  Norways interest in this agreement is as follows:  - Continuing reports of financial indiscipline and lack of compliance with existing financial requirements are indicators of deteriorating PFM performance and fiduciary control at the country level in the management of public finances and resources.  - The FM performance in Bank operations is showing signs of decline with a trend towards more 'unsatisfactory' FM performance and less 'satisfactory' FM performance.  - Possible causes of declining performance - political instability and vested interests being at the center - declining accounting and auditing capacity, increasing financial indiscipline, weak internal audit and conflict of interest, slower decision making, reluctance to recruit international expert consultants, no Auditor General appointed for > 3 years and limited PAC directives follow up, lack of executive response and no sanctions and rewards.Possible ways of responding - short-term measures such as, special purpose reviews and capacity building; and medium-term measures including developing and strengthening PFM institutions, systems and procedures, capacity building and developing social

shortdescription: INTERACTION PROGRAM SUPREME COURT S DIRECTIVE ORDER TO NEPAL GOVERNMENT
projecttitle: Interaction program Supreme Court s Directive Order to Nepal Government
longdescription: Through its advocacy efforts Blue Diamond Society (BDS) has been successful in raising issues related to the Third Gender. A Supreme Court s decision was issued on 21. December 2007 regarding 1) recognition and guarantee of the non-discrimination of persons of the third gender, 2) amendment of all discriminatory laws against sexual and gender minorities and 3) the formation of a 7 member committee to carry out a study and analysis of international Human Rights instruments, and the experience in the countries where the same sex marriage has been recognized and its possible impact on society. This committee is due to submit a report and possible draft legislation to the Government of Nepal. It has been chaired by the Ministry of Health and Population. The Ministry of Women, Children and Social Welfare is delegated the responsibility on working for amendment of the laws that are discriminatory to Sexual and Gender Minorities. Even though the decision was taken three years back regarding sexual minorities, however, its full implementation is yet to be carried out. Moreover, the provisions of the JFA, including any amendments to the JFA adopted by the Parties, shall be complied with. In case of inconsistency between this Agreement and the JFA (as amended), this Agreement shall prevail.The Programme Development Objective is to increase access to and improve quality of school education, particularly basic education (grades 1-8), especially for children from marginalized groups.The Purposes of the Programme are to: a. Ensure equitable access and quality basic education for all children in age group 5-12;b. Expand access to quality Early Childhood Education and Development (ECED) services for children of four years of age to prepare them for basic education;c. purposename: Civilian peace-building, conflict prevention and resolution
channelname: United Nations Entity for Gender Equality and the Empowerment of Women
channelreportedname: UNIFEM - UN Development Fund for Women
longdescription: Support to activities initiated and/or supported by the peace support working group for UN Resolution 1325 on Women, Peace and Security. Norway is chair of the group which consists of UN agencies in Nepal and bilateral donors. The PSWG has as its main task, according to its TOR,  to enhance cooperation and coordination among UN agencies and donors . Key topics that emerge for consideration are: representation of women in government structures and in peace Commissions; reintegration and other support to women associated with armed conflict and their dependents; support for local women s peace initiatives; and security sector reform. Activities include cooperation and coordination, sharing of information and analysis, and advocacy. Relevant follow-up work related to UN Resolution 1820 will also be undertaken.

shortdescription: MUSIC COLLABORATION THROUGH NEPAL MUSIC CENTER - EXIT PHASE
projecttitle: Music collaboration through Nepal Music Center - exit phase
longdescription: NMC has been supported by the Embassy since 2005, and has applied for a new programme period 2010-2012.  Due to budget constraints, the Embassy will provide funds for 2010- 2011, with the intention to support in 2012 as well. During the process NMC has in dialogue with the Embassy worked on the program for the project to integrate the new The project period will be considered a phasing out period for the Norwegian support, and during the period NMC will in close co-operation with the Embassy develop a sound exit strategy. The Embassy considers it important to continue the support for NMC during this period to ensure our efforts and funds will not be lost, and to make sure NMC will be a sustainable institution. The overall goal for the institution is to strengthen and preserve the musical heritage of Nepal; the purpose of the programme is to establish an institution that offers all encompassing curricula for generating pedagogical interest in folk/ ethnic Nepali music.

shortdescription: LOCAL GOVERNANCE AND COMMUNITY DEVELOPMENT PROGRAMME
projecttitle: Local Governance and Community Development Programme
longdescription: The Government of Nepal (GON) has requested the Development Partners (DP) to assist them with the Local Governance and Community Development Programme (LGCDP). The LGCDP is a joint programme between the Government of Nepal (GoN) and development partners that has been formulated through a long, consultative process. This has led to a high level of support among all stakeholders for a programmatic and national approach to local governance and community-led development. The LGCDP is seen as a programme that consolidates the gains achieved under previous programmes. The GoN and the Royal Norwegian Embassy (RNE) have a long history of shared commitment towards local development in the country. The partnership has now taken the form of a programmatic approach with the GoN in the lead and the DPs aligning their support behind the GoNs programme in a harmonized manner. GoalLGCDP's over-arching goal will be to contribute towards poverty reduction through inclusive responsive and accountable local governance and participatory community-led development that will ensure increased involvement of women, Dalits, Adibasi Janajatis, Muslims, Madhesis and other disadvantaged groups in the local

Background: Development cooperation in support of energy is one of the three priority areas for Norway s development cooperation with Nepal. Nepal s hydro power potential can contribute significantly to economic development, among others enabling the government to provide health, education and other socially inclusive welfare services. Hence, there are clear synergies between energy and the Embassy s other priority thematic areas as well as cross-cutting issues as gender equality and social inclusion. Hydro power development is also important in a regional climate context. Despite the recognition that Nepal depends on private investments to utilize its hydro power potential, national and foreign hydro power developers, including Norwegian companies, are not actively backed by the government and public opinion when it comes to the development of specific projects. This is partly due to institutional capacity issues but also to the fact that foreign investments in the hydro power sector is a sensitive issue. On a local level revenue-sharing is a conflict issue.In this context more systematic dialogue and networking with strategic Nepalese energy actors and other donors seems

The Mid Term Review (MTR) on the LGCDP programme identified Social Mobilizing activities as one of the priority areas for focus in order to get the programme on schedule to the original plan. Based on the raised issues in the Mid Term Review Report and the slow pace of the implementation of activities compared to the progress stipulated in the schedule of the programme document, the NACSC meeting on 10th December 2010 decided to conduct an assessment of the status of the implementation of the social mobilisation activities. The effectiveness assessment will comprise an assessment of the following issues:"  the demand side activities to be strengthened according to the Social Mobilisation Policy"  the implementation of the social mobilisation strategy, the definition and modalities of facilitation of community and their participation in the integrated planning process, implementation through user committees, community based organisations, Chairperson Manager s Conference (CMC), federations, child club networks  and their representation, and monitoring"  the performance of local service providers and selection of appropriate agencies "  the quality of social mobilisation"  the

purposename: Decentralisation and support to subnational govt.
longdescription: Development cooperation in support of good governance is one of the three focus and priority areas for Norway s development cooperation with Nepal. Governance support includes both political and economic dimensions, public financial management issues as well support for democracy and the implementation of the peace process. The governance challenges in Nepal are very substantial, including a high and increasing level of corruption at all levels of society.The complex nature of governance support in Nepal implies that there is a considerable need for analytical support to the Embassy and competence enhancement among embassy staff to enable the necessary quality assurance of Norway s support for good governance in Nepal.The project has the following objective:Objective:"  To strengthen the quality assurance of Norway s governance support through analytical and technical support and competence building.

longdescription: The overall purpose of the assignment is to propose how the draft strategy paper for the energy sector can be optimally gender sensitive, with a realistic set of recommendations for how to operationalise it. It is also to ensure that the Embassy s support to Nepal s Energy Sector is in line White paper no 11  On Equal Terms , 2008, and the Action Plan of Action for Women s Rights and Gender Equality in the Development Cooperation (MFA, 2007 - 2013), which outlines the priorities and underlines the two track approach that includes women specific targeted interventions as well as gender mainstreaming of the portfolio.  The embassy has developed its strategic plan on Women s Rights and gender Equality in 2010. The strategic clearly indicates that the resources will be concentrated in selected areas where the relevance to Norway s priority sectors for bilateral cooperation will continue to be a guiding principle in addition to focusing more on WR&GE within the programs and projects that the Embassy is already supporting. longdescription: The main purpose of the end review is to look at issues and questions related to implementation, results and sustainability of the FORMATIVE RESEARCH AND INSTITUTIONAL COOPERATION: NORWEGIAN TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE TO THE EDUCATION FOR ALL (EFA) 2004-09 PROGRAMME IN NEPAL. The intentions and planning of the intervention will not be at the core of the present review, as this was well reviewed in the 2006 Evaluation. The review shall look at whether and to what degree the objectives of FRP & IC have been met. Successes, challenges and issues of particular interest shall be identified and explained. The review shall identify results in terms of the use of research findings in the planning and follow up process of the EFA programme. The review team shall also look into sustainability concerns of the intervention relating to the capacity development of MoE/DOE for evidence-based decision-making, the capacity of CERID for conducting cost-efficient and targeted formative research, and the prospect for future utilization of Formative Research in policy decisions and development of the Nepal education system. shortdescription: SANKALPA - EMPOWERMENT OF WOMEN FOR POLITICAL AND SOCIAL JUSTICE
projecttitle: Sankalpa - Empowerment of Women for Political and Social Justice
longdescription: The goal of the project is to help increase and enhance women representation and rights in the government, political parties, private sectors, at all levels, and ensure that conflict affected women have access to social justice. This will be done through capacity building of various women leaders at grass roots level and women parliamentarians: advocacy and awareness raising on women s representation; Capacity building to national leaders and grass roots women activists on NAP and transitional justice; and through strengthening Sankalpa as an organization by appraising and restructuring its systems and procedures. The primary target groups are thus the district and village level women, key women activists and women s rights organization leaders and Women Human Rights Defenders (WHRDs), conflict affected women and parliamentarians. Civil servants, central level political leaders, local journalists, rural population and CA committee members are the secondary target groups.Purpose: support the implementation of the National Action Plan of UNSCR 1325 and 1820; and increase representation of women in political parties, civil service and national and sub-national governance structures.

purposename: Civilian peace-building, conflict prevention and resolution
longdescription: The Board of Ministers on 1 December 2009 the Nepal Peace Trust Fund (NPTF), originally agreed upon for a three year period until 18 January 2010 only, has been extended for another three-year term until 17 January 2013. The NPTF derives its mandate from the Comprehensive Peace Agreement (CPA) and other relevant peace agreements. The NPTF (a) functions as a coordinating body for peace related initiatives, (b) acts as a funding mechanism for The Government of Nepal (GoN) and donor resources, and (c) monitors the peace process. NPTF is Nepal s own mechanism for support to peace building activities. It is managed by the Ministry of Peace and Reconstruction and GoN is contributing with more than 50 % of the funds. This makes NPTF an important tool to help build Nepalese ownership to the peace process. In spite of the unstable political situation over the last years, including shifting governments, the NPTF has been able to remain relevant and to support important functions in the peace process, for example financing the elections in 2008, the allowances for the Maoist soldiers as well as the maintenance of basic infrastructure in the Maoist cantonments. Norway has supported NPTF si

The Nepal Electricity Transmission Expansion and Supply Improvement Project ( The Project ) will consist of three components: A) Transmission system development, B) Energy Access improvement and C) Small hydropower plant rehabilitation component.  The total budget is USD 128 million, out of which Component A, B and C comprises USD 99 million, USD 12 million and USD 4 million respectively. Contingencies comprise USD 12 million. ADB will provide USD 75 million, Norway USD 25 million and the Government of Nepal/Nepal Electricity Authority (NEA) USD 28 million.  The project period is 2012-2017. NEA will be the executing agency.Project impact is increased access to reliable supply of electricity. Project outcome is improved electricity supply. The target group is the population of Nepal.

purposename: Removal of land mines and explosive remnants of war
channelname: UNITED NATIONS AGENCIES, FUNDS AND COMMISSIONS

longdescription: SDC has been supporting HMRP since 1999. HMRP had very encouraging achievements in the first three phases. such as: i) setting of the maize research priorities. establishing participatory variety selection. validation and certification methodologies. linking research with extension for wider dissemination. ii) certification of nine improved varieties and production of 4.416 MT of improved maize seeds. and iii) linking farmer s feedback to policy decisions through farmer s assessment tests over released varieties. HMRP has contributed to establishing a national research system. linking research with extension and strengthening farmers  groups to produce maize seeds and deal with markets for better and assured prices. This fourth phase will focus on strengthening seeds dissemination channels. developing market links. ensuring the decentralized seed quality assurance system and developing more new maize varieties as the demand remains high.

channelname: United Nations High Commissioner for Human Rights (extrabudgetary contributions only)

longdescription: SDC has been supporting HMRP since 1999. HMRP had very encouraging achievements in the first three phases. such as: i) setting of the maize research priorities. establishing participatory variety selection. validation and certification methodologies. linking research with extension for wider dissemination. ii) certification of nine improved varieties and production of 4.416 MT of improved maize seeds. and iii) linking farmer s feedback to policy decisions through farmer s assessment tests over released varieties. HMRP has contributed to establishing a national research system. linking research with extension and strengthening farmers  groups to produce maize seeds and deal with markets for better and assured prices. This fourth phase will focus on strengthening seeds dissemination channels. developing market links. ensuring the decentralized seed quality assurance system and developing more new maize varieties as the demand remains high.

The Employment Fund s mandate to fund mobile. short-term skills training linked to employment opportunities in the domestic and international labour markets is a relevant strategy. The intervention is targeted at Nepali youth from DAGs below 10th. grade of education. It is contributing towards a long-expected peace dividend for the people. Overall goal: To improve the living conditions of economically and socially disadvantaged youth (16-35 years) in Nepal. Outcomes of the phase: (1) Young women and men. especially those belonging to DAGs are gainfully employed. (2): The Employment Fund Secretariat and its Training & Employment (T&E) service providers are successful institutions in the technical education and vocational training (TEVT) Sector. Coordination and synergies with other projects and actors: This proposed phase will be a harmonized phase with DFID (joint logframe and project document. tripartite agreement with the GoN). The EF has been procuring services from 22 private service providers including the SDC-funded F-Skill project.

shortdescription: RAISING IMPACT OF NATURAL SKILL TESTING
projecttitle: Raising Impact of Natural Skill Testing

longdescription: The Programme s goal is to contribute to reduced emission of GHG and pollution in the construction sector to mitigate global warming. environmental and health degradation. To achieve this the Programme will be playing a stronger role in policy dialogue. advocacy and awareness creation. The context is favourable for a total elimination of the most polluting brick production factories in Kathmandu Valley. The outcomes are as follows: - Building materials and construction entrepreneurs adopt environmental friendly technologies and demonstrate a socially responsible behaviour; - Real estate developers and individuals construct their own houses in urban and semi-urban areas using energy efficient building materials and technologies (ownership and marking); and - Government of Nepal (GoN) have a favourable policy environment promoting clean production technologies in the brick sector (i.e. incentives for cleaner production). To ensure sustainability of the programme the required support services will be institutionalized and privatised. In addition alliances with main donors and international as well as local partners will be established.

purposename: Public sector policy and adm. management
Public sector policy and adm. management

shortdescription: STATE BUILDING AT LOCAL LEVEL PROJECT
projecttitle: State Building at Local Level Project
purposename: Decentralisation and support to subnational govt.
longdescription: The ten-year long conflict (1996-2006) not only had a negative impact on the countries  socio-economic development. but also destroyed and weakened many of its institutions including those at the local level: the village development committees (VDCs) and the district development committees (DDCs). The absence of elected VDC and DDC representatives since 2002 and a weak state have allowed political parties. private sector entrepreneurs and sometimes the administration itself to influence decisions and appropriate resources. SDC proposes to provide a modest budget support to the DDCs in two of its three focus districts: Khotang and Okhaldunga. This budget support will not follow the conventional  modus operandi  by simply putting in funds into the DDC s fund basket. but it will also strengthen the DDCs  technical (mainly planning. monitoring. coordinating) and financial management capacity and accountability. It will assist the DDCs in preparing the periodic and annual district plans that include crucial line agencies and development partners such as SDC. Through this improved coordination. the delivery of services to its citizens. with a focus on the needs of the disadvantaged groups (DAG) is expected to improve. Coupled with the current SDC presence and positioning in these districts. the budget support should allow SDC to increase its leverage and delivery of development outcomes. Moreover. democratic practices are relatively new in Nepal; political parties and armed groups fight over resources and influence at the local level. and most stakeholders including civil society remain divided along party-lines. In such a scenario. the project is also expected to foster a culture of dialogue (and control) among all stakeholders. This should build up experiences and skills that can be used by both the existing local administrations (and the political parties) to prepare for the upcoming transition towards a new federal state. and the new federal unit to possibly build upon. In this sense. the project is also expected to contribute to a smoother transition and prevent conflict. The overall Goal of the entire project is that the DDCs in Khotang and Okhadunga deliver the basic public goods and services as per the aspirations of the citizens and per the provisions of the LSGA 1999 and LGCDP guidelines. The two expected outcomes of the preparation/pilot and the full-fledged phase are that: 1: DDCs have capacity and instruments to manage resources to deliver public goods and services in an inclusive and equitable manner. 2: People. especially the DAGs. have better access to administrative and development services.

Till the end of 2008. SDC cluster area with direct development assistance comprised of Dolakha. Ramechhap and Okhaldhunga districts. The initial credit proposal for NSCFP thus covered these three districts. The new Swiss strategy for Nepal (2009-2012) recommended a gradual reduction of its programme from Dolakha district during the period 2009-2012 and the redirection of its development assistance to Khotang district from 2009 onwards. Khotang is one of the poorest districts of Nepal where forests occupy nearly 51% of total land area. Forests play a critical role in the lives of small farmers and land poor by providing subsistence products and income earning opportunities to supplement the livelihoods. There are more than 200 Community Forestry User Groups (CFUGs) in the district who need support for sustainable and productive management of the forest resources. About 50% of the total population are in the economically active age group (14-59 years). This provides ample opportunities to engage them in pro-poor forest based enterprises and productive and sustainable forest management through community forestry. that increases access of people. mainly the Disadvantaged Groups (DAGs). to forest products and generates local employment. This additional credit proposal seeks support for the purpose. The Nepal Swiss Community Forestry Project (NSCFP) has been supporting the forest sector development in Nepal since 1991. The project has made significant contribution to sustainable management of the forests and to the strengthening of decentralised. inclusive and equitable forest governance. especially in the mid-hills. The most recent review of the 5th phase (July 2004   June 2008) has acknowledged the contribution of the project to livelihood improvements of the DAGs by supporting pro-poor and equitable forest governance locally.

The Goal is to contribute for  improved livelihoods and resilience of poor men. women and children in Nepal . The Purpose is  maximise the contribution of Nepal s forestry sector to inclusive economic growth. poverty reduction and tackling climate change . Coverage will increase from 4 districts (current Swiss coverage) to 61 districts (out of 75 nationally) with full-fledged focused activities in 35 over the next 10 years. Focus is to expand poverty reduction and environmental outcomes of community forestry nationally through wider reach and deeper engagement at different levels.

shortdescription: ASSISTANCE MATRIELLE ET SERVICES D URGENCE
projecttitle: Assistance matrielle et services d urgence
longdescription: The Safer Migration (SaMi) project will contribute to decreasing the socio-economic and psychosocial costs by building the migrants  knowledge about the migration process and their rights and by providing legal and psychosocial support to those who were victimized in the migration process. SaMi aims at increasing the benefits of migration by providing skills trainings for potential migrants especially to people from poor and socially discriminated groups (DAG) of Khotang district. The Government of Nepal together with civil society partners will be supported to identify a strategy to better implement the Foreign Employment Act (FEA).

purposename: Civilian peace-building, conflict prevention and resolution
Civilian peace-building, conflict prevention and resolution

longdescription: Switzerland is recognizing the importance of high quality vegetable seed production through the promotion of private-public partnership among producer cooperatives. NGOs and private seed entrepreneurs in the seed sector. Producing seeds through farmers groups and cooperatives has been a successful approach. which allows a sustainable national seed production. The goal of VSP-III is  to have improved food security and income for the poor and disadvantaged households in remote areas of Nepal . VSP-III will have two major focuses: 1) farm families from poor and DAGs produce and sell quality seeds; and 2) National Seed Board. Nepal Agriculture Research Council and Department of Agriculture enforce decentralised seed production and quality control through public and private institutions. VSP has proven synergies with other SDC supported agricultural projects. such as the Hill Maize Research Project in promoting seed related market and policy issues and the Home garden project in promoting diversification of vegetable production.

purposename: Decentralisation and support to subnational govt.
Decentralisation and support to subnational govt.

longdescription: SDC has been supporting SSMP since 1999. The last three phases have recorded substantial achievements such as: i) major soil nutrient has increased by 17% between 2003 and 2006 in the fields of farmers having adopted SSM practices; ii) farm productivity increment from 30-50% over the same period; iii) over 200 ELFs were trained and provide services to farmers and; iv) over 60 Agriculture. Forests and Environment Committees were revitalised and received funds from VDCs for FtF approach promotion. The experience and learning of SSMP on FtF are thus acknowledged and incorporated in the National Extension Strategy by the Ministry of Agriculture and Cooperatives. The external review of phase III (2009) has recommended a fourth phase. which should focus on up-scaling of proven SSM technologies and on decentralizing FtF approach to the VDC level. This phase will have two major focuses: i) enhance basket of SSM options and support in adoption of improved SSM practices to seize new production and market opportunities; and ii) institutionalize FtF agricultural extension approach to bring services to smallholders and disadvantaged households. It is expected that by the end of the phase. 50.000 households including additional 34.000 new farmers across seven hill districts of Nepal will directly benefit from the project. In terms of exit strategy. it is likely that in order to fully anchor the system. the programme will require a further last phase of 2-4 years to allow for full decentralisation of the planning. management and implementation of agricultural development at VDC level.

The Department of Local Infrastructure Development and Agricultural Roads of the Ministry of Local Development (DoLIDAR/MoLD) is responsible for construction and maintenance of motorable bridges in addition to local roads but it has limited capacity to shoulder this responsibility. Even in the absence of appropriate norms and standards for motorable bridges. it has carried out a few pilot initiatives on motorable bridges. Such experiences have turned out to be over-engineered and expensive. DoLIDAR is thus desirous of a) developing norms and standards appropriate to local roads and b) strengthening its capacities as well as that of the private sector so that these pilots can be replicated. In this regard. GoN has requested SDC to support them with technical assistance. Switzerland has gained significant recognition and visibility in Nepal over the last 4 decades through its engagement in the transport sector. particularly in the trail-bridge and local road sectors. To multiply the benefits to the people. it is time for SDC to embark upon the new sector of motorable bridges. which will not only add value to the existing local roads and trail bridges but also provide opportunities to leverage funds from the GoN (which has committed about $20 million for four years) and other donors. Indeed. to apply labor based approaches in such technology-intensive sector and contribute to improved livelihoods of discriminated and poor groups (DAGs) through skills transfers. construction and maintenance are areas where SDC can make a difference through this programme.

purposename: Civilian peace-building, conflict prevention and resolution

longdescription: The Nepal Peace Trust Fund (NPTF) was created to channel such support to the Government of Nepal (GoN). The Joint Financing Arrangement  for the NPTF was signed between the GoN and a group of donors in February 2007. and implementation of the Fund commenced thereafter. After operating for more than 2 years in a fragile and sensitive political and security environment. the NPTF has successfully implemented 14 projects. while 5 more are ongoing. A further 5 projects are well advanced in the approval pipeline. - Whereas. the government is investing significant finances into NPTF. its capacity is insufficient to finance additional programs out of the regular budget without substantially reducing the resources allocated to basic services or to development activities. The international community is in close consultation with the representative of the UN General Secretary and the UN system. have responded favorably to this initiative. The Donor Advisory Group. which is currently chaired by Switzerland. is formally consulted regarding the choice and design of the individual projects. as well as their monitoring. Switzerland s participation in NPTF places it at the core of this essential instrument for the implementation of the CPA and the international community s efforts to help prevent the country s relapse into conflict. It will also strengthen the existing Swiss engagement in peacebuilding in Nepal. including the work of a PA IV funded senior peace advisor. support and substantive contributions to the constitutional debate. the promotion of human rights. the re-creation of inclusive governance institutions in specific districts and villages as well as the peace sensitive management of the bilateral development program.

SDC has been supporting the small irrigation sector since August 2006 with Local Infrastructure for Livelihood Improvement (LILI) Phase I. which has also been co-funded by Helvetas under its strategic partnership with DFID and executed by Helvetas. The target groups for LILI include marginalized and small farmers having farming-land below 0.25 hectare. The achievements of LILI Phase I are encouraging. A total of 64 small irrigation schemes. 3 vegetable collection centres and 29 public-buildings are expected to be completed by end of the Phase I. July 2009. The irrigation has been the main component. LILI monitoring report (March 2009) shows that about 88% LILI-supported farmers have diversified/ intensified cropping practices. and thus increased annual agriculture production by 50%. LILI Phase I has also improved knowledge and capacity of DDCs and local institutions/organizations to build and manage farmers-managed small irrigations. As suggested by the Internal Project Review and a Special Study carried out by SDC Coof. the support to public-buildings will discontinue in Phase II in order to be more focused to the small irrigation systems. Based on good experience made during Phase I. a second phase of four years is proposed. The Goal of LILI phase II is to contribute to  Improved food security of small farmers in the rural areas of eight districts .

The Programme is being managed by the DRSP Support Unit. The district administrations and the people of the district are the main partners and the Department of Local Infrastructure Development and Agricultural Roads (DoLIDAR) under the Ministry of Local Development (MoLD) is the coordinating and monitoring agency. The Project Support Unit (PSU) supports the capacity building in the districts. for implementation of rural infrastructure and community development activities. The District Development Committees (DDC) and local groups implement the works. with support from the PSU. DoLIDAR is responsible for the Planning. Coordination. Fund flow and Monitoring of the Programme. SDC has inducted many good practices across the rural road projects in Nepal. The green roads concept. that adopts the LEP approach. drawn from Swiss experience. has been adopted nationally. Until recently unheard issues of workers  welfare are now being translated into policy. that include insurance. work safety. equal wage for equal work and facilities that help women to participate. District Transport Master Plans that DRSP pioneered are being used widely. A Gender policy for rural transport infrastructure is shortly expected to be endorsed by GoN. These distinctive qualities helped SDC to upscale its activities through collaborations with other donors. particularly in the ADB funded Decentralised Rural Infrastructure and Livelihoods Project and ADB/DFID/OFID Rural Reconstruction and Rehabilitation Project. Most of these innovations are expected to form a backbone for the SWAp framework that the government aims to establish by end 2011. While this Phase IV will be the final one in the current set-up. SDC sees opportunities in continuing its engagement in the context of a SWAp framework.

The Project contributes to reducing rural poverty in very poor/remote hill and mountain regions in 18 districts of Nepal. by widening access to social services/economic opportunities. It will bring economic benefits among people by improving their access to markets and services. It will reduce poverty by generating 4.7 million person days of off-farm employment. of which 50% goes to disadvantaged groups (DAGs) and directly benefiting 0.9 million through road access in the Zone of Influence (ZoI). It will ensure increased participation of DAGs and women. Since the DRILP project started in 2005. over 455 km of roads constructed and rehabilitated. Key outputs from 2012-2015: (1) 260 km of rural roads are built (200 km new construction and 60 km upgraded); 1200 km of roads maintained; Around 200 other small community infrastructures will be built/rehabilitated; 4.7 mio person days of employment created at local level; 60% of them are from DAGs. (2) Capacity of 18 District Development Committees (DDCs) strengthened in planning. implementation and management of local infrastructure projects; 40% women and DAGs are represented and able to influence decisions in building groups; Skills of 3000 people (40% of which are women and 60% are DAGs) enhanced. - Overall goal: The programme s goal is to contribute towards poverty reduction through enhanced mobility of isolated rural people. This will have an impact on overall local economic development through improved access to goods and social services and economic opportunities in 18 very poor and remote hill and mountain districts of Nepal.

The Programme is being managed by the DRSP Support Unit. The district administrations and the people of the district are the main partners and the Department of Local Infrastructure Development and Agricultural Roads (DoLIDAR) under the Ministry of Local Development (MoLD) is the coordinating and monitoring agency. The Project Support Unit (PSU) supports the capacity building in the districts. for implementation of rural infrastructure and community development activities. The District Development Committees (DDC) and local groups implement the works. with support from the PSU. DoLIDAR is responsible for the Planning. Coordination. These distinctive qualities helped SDC to upscale its activities through collaborations with other donors. particularly in the ADB funded Decentralised Rural Infrastructure and Livelihoods Project and ADB/DFID/OFID Rural Reconstruction and Rehabilitation Project. SDC sees opportunities in continuing its engagement in the context of a SWAp framework.

A total of 64 small irrigation schemes. 3 vegetable collection centres and 29 public-buildings are expected to be completed by end of the Phase I. July 2009. The Programme will bring economic benefits among poor communities. by improving access to markets and services. It also addresses poverty by generating off-farm employment of 2600 person days per bridge directly. It will ensure increased participation of disadvantaged groups and women in bridge building initiatives and empower them for better governance. As a result of these Swiss supports. a Sector Wide Approach is conceived by GoN with WB. ADB. DFID and SDC.

Through its project planning and implementation approach RHDP has empowered community groups. especially women. and also influenced the village development committees (VDCs) to integrate community health demands in VDC planning. and thus contributed to local state building and better service delivery. After 17 years of cooperation. this will be the last phase of RHDP that will focus on consolidation and sustainability. As in the past. the project will aim at improving overall health status of people. especially of women. poor and disadvantaged groups in remote areas of Dolakha. Ramechhap and Okhaldhunga districts. RHDP will continue to strengthen the linkage between demand and supply through positively changing health seeking behaviour of community people. especially women (demand side) and to capacitate the local health service providers / promoters. in collaboration with local authorities. to respond to priority health needs of the people (supply side). Primary beneficiaries will be women. children. adolescents. and men. with special attention to Dalits and Janajatis. The operational strategy is based on previous RHDP achievements and lessons and is in line with the TYIP and national health sector policies as well as with the new Swiss Cooperation Strategy for Nepal 2009-2012. Identified challenges and weaknesses will be taken into account with a special focus on project sustainability. intensified collaboration with other health and development actors and agencies and sequenced phasing out of RHDP s interventions. An exit plan with milestones has been prepared.

Through its project planning and implementation approach RHDP has empowered community groups. especially women. and also influenced the village development committees (VDCs) to integrate community health demands in VDC planning. and thus contributed to local state building and better service delivery. After 17 years of cooperation. this will be the last phase of RHDP that will focus on consolidation and sustainability. As in the past. the project will aim at improving overall health status of people. especially of women. poor and disadvantaged groups in remote areas of Dolakha. Ramechhap and Okhaldhunga districts. RHDP will continue to strengthen the linkage between demand and supply through positively changing health seeking behaviour of community people. especially women (demand side) and to capacitate the local health service providers / promoters. in collaboration with local authorities. to respond to priority health needs of the people (supply side). Primary beneficiaries will be women. children. adolescents. and men. with special attention to Dalits and Janajatis. The operational strategy is based on previous RHDP achievements and lessons and is in line with the TYIP and national health sector policies as well as with the new Swiss Cooperation Strategy for Nepal 2009-2012. Identified challenges and weaknesses will be taken into account with a special focus on project sustainability. intensified collaboration with other health and development actors and agencies and sequenced phasing out of RHDP s interventions. An exit plan with milestones has been prepared.

shortdescription: RIVER PROTECTION WORKS IN EAST CHITWAN
projecttitle: River Protection Works in East Chitwan
longdescription: The main goal of the project is to safeguard the people and assets of eastern Chitwan from flood related disaster and improve their livelihoods and food security. (1) Local communities  are safe from water induced natural disaster; (2) Local communities safeguard their livelihoods in an inclusive way; (3) The Central Government is aware of Chitwan s specific needs for watershed management. Outputs (1): Local communities along Rapti River and in the project VDCs build and rehabilitate river protection works. Some indicators of success are: i) Launching aprons and spurs of the 18 Kms long dykes at appropriate locations are rehabilitated/constructed; ii) Height of the dyke at appropriate places is increased; iii) Debris collected below the Lothar bridge is removed and is used for increasing the height of the dyke; iv) Appropriate protection works on some inner streams are carried out. (2): Local communities rehabilitate the irrigation canals originating from Rapti river. Some indicators of success are : i) Intake of the irrigation canal is adjusted to the new river levels; ii) 7 850 ha of agricultural land will remain cultivated throughout the year with irrigated water; iii) the beneficiary farmers will be benefiting from sustained consumption of food and incomes from the sale of surplus produces. (3): User s committee and its sub committees formed to implement the works. Some indicators of success are: i) Inclusive users committees and its sub committees are formed; ii) District Development Committee (DDCs). respective VDCs. Buffer zone users committees contribute to protection works; iv) Users committees (UCs) are responsible for routine and minor maintenance of the dykes. (4): Communities. VDCs and the DDC strengthen their capacity to engage in dialogues with the central Government on the need to undertake larger integrated watershed management initiatives. Some indicators of success are: i) a study for a long term and sustainable solution with recommendation is available; ii) DDC representatives and the main political parties lobby for budget for the implementation of the recommendation of the study.

shortdescription: TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE TO SKILL FOR EMPLOYMENT PROJECT
projecttitle: Technical Assistance to Skill for Employment Project

purposename: Public sector policy and adm. management
longdescription: LGCDP's over-arching goal is to contribute towards poverty reduction through inclusive responsive and accountable local governance and participatory community-led development that will ensure increased involvement of women. Dalits. Adibasi Janajatis. Muslims. Madhesis. disadvantaged groups in the local governance process. The programme will contribute towards attaining the goal through achieving its three major Programme Outcomes: (1) Citizens and communities empowered to exercise their voice and to engage actively with local governments on resource allocation and decision making; (2) Increased capacity of local governments to manage resources and deliver basic services in an inclusive and equitable manner; and (3) Strengthened policy and national institutional framework for decentralization. devolution and community development.

shortdescription: CONTRIBUTION TO PEACE PROCESS IN NEPAL
projecttitle: Contribution to peace process in Nepal
purposename: Civilian peace-building, conflict prevention and resolution
longdescription: In November 2006 a Comprehensive Peace Accord was signed by the CPN (Maoist) and the Government of Nepal that ended 10 years of armed conflict. Key provisions of the agreement have yet to be implemented. Switzerland contributes in various ways to the peace process. in particular through its Senior Peacebuilding Advisor in Nepal. He provides support for the implementation of the provisions of the Comprehensive Peace Accord. inter alia through small projects like workshops. seminars and capacity building. These activities are financed with a larger framework credit to keep the administrative input low.

purposename: Civilian peace-building, conflict prevention and resolution
longdescription: The main focus of PBI-Nepal is the provision of protective accompaniment to human rights defenders and organisations facing difficulties in carrying out their work. As such. team members physically accompany local civil society activists at risk. deterring potential threats and encouraging increased efforts for the promotion of peaceful solutions to armed conflict and for the respect of human rights. Accompaniment is only provided after an assessment of the request and of the current situation. Furthermore. it is contingent upon networking with local authorities.

purposename: Civilian peace-building, conflict prevention and resolution
longdescription: The project has four components; first. it intends to gather information on major issues that are contributing to human security challenges in Tarai. The research findings will be published and made public and also used for policy advocacy. Second. top political leaders from Tarai will be consulted to talk on reports for policy change. Third. four episodes of television program will be produced and aired through television based on the research findings. Fourth. two trainings on human security issues will be organized for Tarai-based human rights defenders.

purposename: Civilian peace-building, conflict prevention and resolution
longdescription: In November 2006 a Comprehensive Peace Accord was signed by the CPN (Maoist) and the Government of Nepal that ended 10 years of armed conflict. The armed conflict has claimed more than 15.000 lives and many people suffered from human rights violations from all sides. Switzerland contributed in various ways to the peace process by being actively engaged in the informal facilitation of the peace talks. The Senior Adviser for Peacebuilding in Nepal provides support for the implementation of the provisions of the Comprehensive Peace Accord. including democratic state-building and the promotion of human security. Small projects like workshops. seminars and capacity building in the area of state restructuring. constitutional affairs. federalism and SSR have been a useful instrument. These activities are financed with a larger framework credit to keep the administrative input low.

shortdescription: PROMOTING DIALOGUE THROUGH NEPAL TRANSITION TO PEACE FORUM (NTTP)
projecttitle: Promoting dialogue through Nepal Transition to Peace Forum (NTTP)
purposename: Civilian peace-building, conflict prevention and resolution
longdescription: This project aims to further support the Nepal Transition to Peace Forum in its function as an accepted and trusted dialogue space for political parties. The support is channeled through The Asia Foundation. which manages the work of the Nepal Transition to Peace Forum. The forum is facilitated by two well-respected national facilitators and it includes the participation of second-tier politicians from major political parties. The work of the forum will be crucial for the final stages of the constitution drafting as well as for the following consultation and implementation processes. Switzerland is participating in the process through the Swiss Senior Advisor for Peacebuilding who assists the NTTP facilitators.

purposename: Civilian peace-building, conflict prevention and resolution
Civilian peace-building, conflict prevention and resolution

shortdescription: TV DEBATE ON CONSTITUTION DRAFTING IN NEPAL
projecttitle: TV Debate on Constitution Drafting in Nepal
longdescription: In November 2006 a Comprehensive Peace Accord was signed by the CPN (Maoist) and the Government of Nepal that ended ten years of armed conflict. In April 2008 a Constituent Assembly (CA) was elected to draft a new constitution that should reflect the aspiration of Nepali people. and guarantee the fundamental rights. rule of law and democratic values. A TV programme on the content and the process of constitution making will encourage an extensive debate. discussion. and dialogues as to make sure persons from all walks of life have taken part in constitution making process and have some contribution. This process is not only important in getting feedbacks to fill up lacunas but also provide the peoples with sense of ownership to the new constitution.

The project seeks to overcome imbalance and inequalities being faced by minority groups. especially women. Madheshi. Dalits. religious and linguistic groups by strengthening capacity of minority civil society to engage in targeted advocacy to demand for the incorporation and implementation of the minority rights provisions in the Constitution. It will also focus on sensitizing a wide range of stakeholders (from minority activists to representatives of government) on the importance of the human rights of minority and indigenous communities. the national and international instruments existing to protect those and how to ensure that appropriate mechanisms are adopted and implemented to guarantee the respect of these rights.

The project aims to monitor the voter's registration program. which is carried out by the Election Commission of Nepal. It will measure its effectiveness and examines the lapses. weaknesses of the past voters registration system in light of current method to advance fair. inclusive and appropriate registration.

To support Nepal's Constituent Assembly (CA) in its task to concretise the agreement in the peace accord to restructure the state. the accompaniment and support to the discussion about federalism. as requested by the political parties. the administration. the relevant committees in the CA. and civil society organisations. is an important ongoing task of the Special Adviser for Peace Building/Nepal (SAPB/N). This project aims at creating an interactive database for the users - influentials of the CA. politicians. but also civil society - themselves to test and develop models of federalisation and their repercussions on wealth distribution in Nepal. Besides 'identity' (language. cast. religion). the natural resources. their geographical distribution and the consequences in the form of taxes and their distribution (between and amongst the future states. the local and the national level). are one of the most important criteria which is considered to be central for the coming decision making process about the type of federalism Nepal will go for in the coming years.

shortdescription: SUPPORT VICTIMS OF INTERNATIONAL CRIMES IN NEPAL IN ORDER TO OBTAIN JUSTICE
projecttitle: Support Victims of international crimes in Nepal in order to obtain justice
longdescription: The overall aim of the project is to help victims of international crimes in Nepal obtain justice by offering free legal support to victims. by submitting cases to the UN Human Rights Committee and by training local lawyers and NGO representatives the necessary tools for independently submitting cases to international human rights bodies in the future.

purposename: Civilian peace-building, conflict prevention and resolution
longdescription: Switzerland was asked to facilitate confidential negotiations between three members of the major parties and a politician from the Madhesh in Switzerland. The negotiations should create a consensus working draft that packages agreements on three wide topics - power sharing. integration and consultation writing - that will break the current deadlock and complete the key agreed elements in the peace process.

purposename: Civilian peace-building, conflict prevention and resolution
channelname: UNITED NATIONS AGENCIES, FUNDS AND COMMISSIONS
longdescription: Following UNMIN's withdrawal on 15 January 2011. in accordance with Security Council resolution 1939 (2010). the Secretary-General assured the Nepali public and political parties that the UN will continue to support the peace process. including through his political engagement. Switzerland will support the running of the DPA office in the first 6 months.

shortdescription: CONTRIBUTION TO PEACE APPEAL FOUNDATION 'NEPAL'S TRANSITION TO PEACE PROCESS' (NTTP)
projecttitle: Contribution to Peace Appeal Foundation 'Nepal's Transition to Peace Process' (NTTP)
purposename: Civilian peace-building, conflict prevention and resolution
longdescription: To support the national facilitators during this difficult phase of Nepal's peace process and to provide inputs in the necessary discussions. workshops and various meetings with political parties. as well for coaching and common reflection on the role of the facilitation in the future. the experienced earlier technical adviser of the 'Nepal's Transition to Peace Process' NTTP (during 2005 - 2008). Mr. Hannes Siebert of Peace Appeal Foundation. was requested by the national facilitators to undertake a support mission to Nepal in November/December 2009. The Special Adviser for Peace Building/Nepal is part of this working context and was asked to finance this mission. PDIV will therefore support the mission with USD 17'000.

purposename: Decentralisation and support to subnational govt.
channelname: University, college or other teaching institution, research institute or think-tank
longdescription: The conference aims on one side to draw big lines of action for the coming years and on the other hand to demonstrate the enormous political changes. which took place the last 20 years in Nepal. as too many people in the country can't see any movement in politics and society. The contributions of the participants illustrating these lines on one side and the positive changes on the other should then be used by the politicians as lessons learnt for their work.

purposename: Decentralisation and support to subnational govt.
longdescription: As the constitution-making process is part of the peace process in Nepal. Switzerland has been supporting the constitution-making process by sending a constitutional expert. This expert has been working jointly with the Swiss Peacebuilding Advisor for the last two years. It was decided to prolong the engagement of the constitutional expert for another 6 months as the Constitution-making. which was supposed to be concluded by May 2010. had to be prolonged by twelve months for different reasons. In order to guarantee a smooth realization of her engagement. her running budget has to be prolonged. too.

purposename: Decentralisation and support to subnational govt.
longdescription: Nepal is undergoing a major transition to introduce a system of democratic federal governance. One of the immediate challenges after Nepal adopts a federal constitution is to design and implement a suitable system of fiscal transfers to provide the new decentralized units with suitable financial means. This project aims to increase knowledge in designing the system of fiscal transfers with representatives of relevant Nepali institutions and political leaders by carrying out a consultation process on fiscal transfers leading to the publication of conclusions on a Design and Implementation Plan.

Taking advantage of the current political situation and the state of the constitution making process in Nepal. the project aims of sensitizing and brokering information about contentious constitutional and political issues that have not yet been solved or addressed in this process respectively in the thematic reports of the respective committees of the Constituent Assembly (CA). at making an informed political participation. at conducting opinion polls about these issues and at promoting consensus in this respect among the Terai based civil society and political parties at district and regional level.  By subsequently transmitting these issues. the opinions and consensus about them to national level politicians and especially to the CA and its representatives. the project aims at advancing the constitution making process and at incorporating the voices of marginalized Madheshi People into this process and the new constitution.

purposename: Decentralisation and support to subnational govt.
Decentralisation and support to subnational govt.
longdescription: Ethiopia will host the 5th International Conference on Federalism from December in partnership with the Forum of Federations. The theme of the 5th International Conference is 'Equality and Unity in Diversity for Development'. which reflects the need for sustainable development in federal. federalizing or decentralizing countries in Africa and other non-Western regions. It will be discussed under five main topics. which are of extreme relevance to Nepal and its current political situation. as it attempts to transition to federalism. As such. the inclusion of participants from Nepal will allow for comparative experiences to be shared and brought back to Nepal in an attempt to support the constitution writing process. The participation of Nepal in the conference will support the overall goal and objectives of the Forum's ongoing Nepal program. Federalism in Nepal: Supporting Nepal's Constitutional Transition. funded by Switzerland (SDC).

NGO's as well as human rights defenders play a crucial role in the conflict transformation process in Nepal. Therefore PBI Nepal aims at strengthening local civil society actors who fight against impunity. for the rule of law as well as for women's and minority rights. By providing human rights defenders who are threatened by political violence with protective accompaniment. PBI Nepal creates the necessary space for their work. PBI Switzerland's main role within the same project focuses on advocacy. awareness raising as well as networking.

shortdescription: NGO SUPPORT / NEPAL TOURISM, OUTDOOR AND ENVIRONMENT DEVELOPMENT PROJECT
projecttitle: NGO Support / Nepal tourism, outdoor and environment development project
longdescription: Aims: sustainable development (including social, economic and environmental sustainability) of trekking related tourism in selected areas of Katmandu Valley (Dhulikhel); increase of environmental awareness among local inhabitants, private sector and visiting tourists. Activities: construct trekking-related facilities (toilets, information boards, signpost tracks, resting places); organise waste management; environmental awareness raising; organise campaigns for better environment; children's environmental education.

shortdescription: INTEGRATING SEXUAL AND REPRODUCTIVE HEALTH AND BIODIVERSITY
projecttitle: Integrating Sexual and Reproductive Health and Biodiversity
channelreportedname: Finnish NGO, Maailman Luonnon Sti, WWF Suomen Raha
geography: Districts of Dang, Chitwan, Banke, Bardiya and Kailali, Terai, Nepal
longdescription: The project implements an integrated population, health and environment (PHE) approach. The objective is improved sustainable management of natural resources and increased access to sexual and reproductive health (SRH) services contributing to improved livelihood in environmentally critical areas of Terai Arc Landscape. Income generating activities, biodiversity conservation and SRH rights and services are promoted. Food security and climate change adaptation with some mitigation activities, as well as capacities of community-based organisations are developed.

shortdescription: SUPPORT TO NATIONAL HUMAN RIGHTS COMMISSION OF NEPAL
projecttitle: Support to National Human Rights Commission of Nepal
channelreportedname: Recipient Government, National Human Rights Commission (NHRC)
longdescription: National Human Rights Commission, NHRC, is a central constitutional human rights body in Nepal. Commission s work focuses on monitoring transitional justice and human rights promotion. Finland with other donors has been supporting a UNDP s capacity building project. This project will further enhance the Commission s capacity especially in the fields that intertwine with other Finnish involvement, such as, investigation of human rights violations and human rights work in education sector. The project duration is 18 months during 2010-2012. The total budget is 185 000 euros.

shortdescription: ADMINISTRATIVE COST OF MFA MISSIONS ABROAD FOR NEPAL
projecttitle: Administrative cost of MFA missions abroad for NEPAL
longdescription: Administrative cost of MFA missions abroad for NEPAL. Costs generated from the Embassy of Finland

shortdescription: ENHANCING CHILD PROTECTION SYSTEM IN NEPAL
projecttitle: Enhancing Child Protection System in Nepal
longdescription: In spite of commitment, government of Nepal has been inefficient to meet the requirements for protecting children from different forms of abuse, violence and exploitation. NGOs have become crucial actors, though the actions of NGOs are also questioned and sometimes their capacities and skills are also questioned. The government child protection policies are still waiting for formal adaptation. The project aims at establishing child protection system and mechanism at local level with appropriate policy guidance. Specific objectives are: promotion of national child protection network, application of child protection policies, and strengthening of local child protection committees. The project has component of advocacy, network building, capacity building, and production and sharing of resource materials.

shortdescription: OUR SCHOOL IS A GOOD SCHOOL PRIMARY EDUCATION DEVELOPMENT PROJECT
projecttitle: Our school is a good school primary education development project
longdescription: Nepal s education system can t offer child friendly school environment to all. Project s development problem is that public schools and teachers lack adequate teaching learning methods and infrastructure resulting children dropping out of schools. This project aims to strengthen teacher s role in their community and inside the education system, form learning network among teachers, promote child s rights and participation in schools and sensitize stakeholders to take responsible role for implementation. Through these activities the objective of this project: Child Friendly School concept is widely accepted and practiced in public schools in the project area. Motivated and skilful teachers and inspiring and safe school environment are available to all the children at the 14 schools in 5 VDCs will be reached.

shortdescription: INTEGRATING MENTAL HEALTH IN PRIMARY HEALTH CARE
projecttitle: Integrating mental health in primary health care
channelreportedname: Finnish NGO, Lkrin Sosiaalinen Vastuu ry
longdescription: Improving the quality of and the access to mental health services in Nepals Dang district. Alleviating the stigma associated with mental illness.

shortdescription: MULTI STAKEHOLDER FOREST SECTOR SUPPORT; TRANSITION PHASE
projecttitle: Multi stakeholder forest sector support; transition phase
longdescription: The Swiss Agency for Development and Cooperation (SDC) acting through the Embassy of Switzerland has a lead role in the implementation of the Programme during 2011-2015. After the three year transition phase the programme is expected to be handed over to a national entity. The ultimate aim of the programme is to become a National Forestry Fund administered by the Government of Nepal. During the transition phase 22 districts will be covered. The programme area will eventually be extended to 61 districts in Nepal.
TA for skills development integration in to the curriculum of grades 6-8.

projecttitle: Frame Agreement with NGO (Finn Church Aid)

The project's aim is to develop the Nepalese trade unions in the financing sector by training and cooperation.

The project's areas of intervention are: 1: Strengthening and Creating Green Jobs; 2: Addressing the Impact of Climate Change in Human and Natural Systems; 3: Enhancing the Productivity of Natural Systems; 4: Capacity Building and raising awareness on trade union rights and conservation.

shortdescription: NGO SUPPORT / HEALTH EDUCATION & TOBACCO INTERVENTION PROGRAMME (HETIP)
projecttitle: NGO Support / Health Education & Tobacco Intervention Programme (HETIP)
longdescription: Health Education & Tobacco Intervention Programme (HETIP). Enhancement of healthier lifestyles.

shortdescription: RURAL WATER SUPPLY AND SANITATION PROJECT IN WESTERN NEPAL
projecttitle: Rural Water Supply and Sanitation Project in Western Nepal
longdescription: RWSSP-WN replicates the finished RWSSSP in the adjacent zones to Lumbini Zone in order to transfer the experience to the new districts. In addition the Project continues the work on the arsenic migitation and sanitation that has been established by the RWSSSP. The inclusion of the village-level irrigation, hydroelectricity and solid waste components will be considered on the basis of the experience gained from the RWVRMP.

The overall objective of the project is to increase biodiesel feedstock and promote clean energy and rural income generation through management and cultivation of Jatropha curcas.Specific objectives are 1)to analyze the land use patterns and suitability for Jatropha curcas cultivation, 2)to increase awareness on collection, management and cultivation of Jatropha curcas, 3)to produce Jatropha seedlings for commercial plantation,  4)to improve local economy through Jatropha seed production, 5)to establish marketing linkage between Jatropha producers and biodiesel company, 6)to conduct trial experiment for optimization of Jatropha genotype and place, 7)to conduct a pilot scale biodiesel testing program.

Overall objective: To contribute to achieve the millennium development goal (MDG) through providing educational, economical opportunities and empowering to the Musahar children and adult who have the lowest socioeconomic status in Siraha and Saptari districts of Nepal by the end of February 2011. Specific objectives:  1.To increase access of Musahar children to educational opportunity through educational campaign, tuition and extra supports. 2.To form and strengthen saving and credits groups in Musahar community through reflect literacy classes to raise the literacy rate of adult Musahars (both women and men) 3.To enhance the institutional capacity of the Rastriya Musahar Uthan Samaj (RMUS) for monitoring, advocacy and networking with local level networks for Musahar rights.

Overall objective: To raise the voice of Dalit from local level by improving the quality and quantity of media coverage on issues of Dalit, its rights, diversity and social inclusion. Increase Dalit journalists within and outside the Dalit organizations, Sensitize the non-dalit journalists and media houses on dalit issues to develop and mainstream dalit issues into their regular programme, Institutionalization of Radio Jagaran through internal system development and connecting with people and institutions under cooperative model.
Increase income generation opportunities and maintain social peace and harmony among marginalized women/youth of Mahottari district through cooperative development

geography: Siraha, Sindhuli, Ramechhap, and Dolakha ( Five VDCs in each districts)
longdescription: Formation of VDC and district level women rights defenders groups and networks followed by their capacity building. Formation and mobilization of children clubs Prepare mobile Fact Finding Mission at district levels; prepare baseline information and dissemination on women and children right through press release, media briefs and occasional reports. Increased access of women and children to government service provisions and monitoring of its quality and effectiveness through public hearing. Media Monitoring accompanied with the publication of news bulletin, press release and case studies on human rights issue.

geography: Baitadi, Darchula, Doti, Kailali, Dadeldhura, Myagdi, Nawalparasi, Arghakhanchi, Panchthar, Ilam
longdescription: To use Kathmandu International Mountain Film Festival (KIMFF) 2010 films, being a powerful medium, to advance better sensitivity and understanding among people on contemporary issues facing Nepali society with special focus on migrant labour, biodiversity, climate change and environment, cultural diversity, gender and development priorities. KIMFF hopes not only to encourage a deeper understanding of the socio-economic, cultural, and political realities of the country but also to create a sense that the significance of these issues is shared. The growing distance and complexity of the relationship between the centre and the districts is what KIMFF seeks to narrow down. The impetus for the festival has always been the trust of the community in the capability of the audio-visual medium in creating social and economic transformation.

The overall objective of the program is to improve the socio-economic conditions of rural poor households of Kanchanpur district of Far Western Nepal through diversified sustainable production , processing, enterprise development and marketing of organically produced MAPs. Specific objectives; Identify the sources of MAPs and traditional knowledge and practicesImprove the MAPs management practices of CFUGs, Develop community based MAPs enterprises, establish local level processing centre as common facility centre , identify and analyse potential national and international markets, identify and develop technology and an extension package at local, national and international levels.

Identify the community based organization or traditional institutions at targeted community to assure the identification of needy youths under this project, Coordinate with them (CBOs, community level structure for example women's group, child Clubs), targeted Community, VDC and District Level governmental line agencies, CBOs and NGOs, Develop, finalize and share trainees selection criteria with all stakeholders, Collect profiles of prospective youths and conduct interview with them, Select and finalize the trainees and arrange their arrival at training center, Orient about the training and enroll them , Impart vocational training including soft skills and life skill lessons, Conduct exposure visit in related factories, workshop and working locations as per training, Provide career guidance and psychosocial counseling support, Conduct Exposure Visit and arrange OJT, Support the graduates
